question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('1440324e-0ef4-49b9-9022-987a965f4a74'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE

RECEIVED

For the questions provided, I will consider the relationships between the events and their implications for the probabilities assigned to each.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event has a certain level of uncertainty, as it depends on Elon Musk's schedule and willingness to attend. Given his previous engagements and interest in Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability of this happening.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated at a certain probability, not_P should be 1 minus that probability. This relationship must hold true.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is closely related to P and should share the same probability, as it essentially asks the same thing but in a different form. 

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024)**: Given the ongoing interest in Bitcoin and Musk’s influence in the cryptocurrency space, I would assign a reasonable probability to this event occurring.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q happen)**: This probability must take into account both events happening simultaneously. The probability of P_and_Q is generally less than or equal to the individual probabilities of P and Q, and it cannot exceed the probability of either event occurring alone.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q happens)**: This probability must be calculated as the probability of P plus the probability of Q minus the probability of both happening (P_and_Q). This ensures that we do not double-count the scenarios where both events occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happens and P does not)**: This probability is interesting because it assesses the situation where Musk makes a statement about Bitcoin but does not attend the conference. This should be less than or equal to the probability of Q.

8. **Q_given_P (If P happens, will Q happen?)**: This conditional probability assesses the likelihood of Q occurring given that P has occurred. It should be directly influenced by the relationship between P and Q.

In summary, I will ensure that the probabilities assigned to each event adhere to the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between P and not_P, as well as the calculations for P_and_Q and P_or_Q. This will involve careful estimation based on the interdependencies of the events.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.50,
P_or_Q: 0.85,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.77

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.85 + 0.50 - 0.70 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.50 <= min(0.65, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.70) <= 0.85 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.70) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.85 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.77 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

cond consistency check failed!

0.65

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

In this set of questions, we are assessing the likelihood of Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and his public statements about Bitcoin in 2024. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question hinges on Musk's attendance at a specific event. Given Musk's history with Bitcoin, I estimate this probability to be moderately high, around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is estimated at 0.65, then not_P should be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I will keep it at 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: Given Musk's active role in the cryptocurrency space and his tendency to make public comments, I estimate this probability to be high, around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and (2) he publicly discusses Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: The probability of both events happening together is less than either occurring independently, so I estimate this to be around 0.45.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: (a) Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024 or (b) he makes a public statement about Bitcoin in 2024?)**: This should be higher than either P or Q individually, so I estimate this at 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both of the following occur: (1) Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin and (2) he does not show up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This scenario is plausible, so I estimate this probability at 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: If he attends the event, it is likely he will make a statement, so I estimate this at 0.75.

In summary, P and not_P are complementary, and I must ensure that the other relationships between the questions also respect the consistency rules. For example, the estimates for P_and_Q and Q_and_not_P must be reflective of their respective probabilities and relationships with P and Q.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.45,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.80 + 0.45 - 0.70 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.45 <= min(0.65, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.70) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.70) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.80 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.45 / 0.75 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's attendance and statements about Bitcoin, we can analyze the relationships and probabilities based on logical dependencies and potential outcomes.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** and **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** are complementary events. If we estimate a probability for P, then not_P should equal 1 - P. This relationship will guide our estimates for these two variables.

2. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)** is closely related to P, and we can assume it has a similar probability since both questions revolve around the same event. Therefore, para_P should have a probability close to that of P.

3. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)** is independent of P and not_P, as it does not rely on his attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville event. However, we can estimate its probability based on Musk's previous engagement with Bitcoin.

4. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)** depends on both P and Q being true. We can estimate this using the multiplication rule for independent events, which means P_and_Q should be less than or equal to the smaller of P and Q.

5. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)** will be influenced by both P and Q. The probability of P_or_Q should be calculated as the sum of P and Q minus the probability of both occurring (P_and_Q).

6. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not P occurs?)** indicates that Q happens but P does not. This requires careful consideration since it involves both independent and dependent relationships.

7. **Q_given_P (Given P occurs, will Q occur?)** is a conditional probability that can be estimated based on the likelihood of Q occurring if P is true. This can be a bit tricky as it requires understanding how likely Q is when we know P is true.

In summary, the relationships between these questions are pivotal in determining their probabilities. The complementary nature of P and not_P, along with the independence of Q, will help in establishing a consistent set of probability estimates that adhere to the consistency rules.

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's attendance and statements at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, I will consider several factors to determine the probability estimates. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is contingent on Musk's schedule and interest in attending Bitcoin-related events. Given his previous engagements and the significance of Bitcoin in his public persona, I estimate a moderate probability of around 0.65 for this event.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35, reflecting the possibility that he may not attend.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is closely related to P, and since it essentially asks the same thing, I will assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: Considering Musk's previous engagement with Bitcoin and his tendency to make public statements, I estimate this probability to be slightly higher, around 0.75.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The probability of both events occurring is influenced by their independence. Given that both events could occur simultaneously, I estimate this probability to be 0.50.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone. I will estimate it at 0.85, considering the likelihood of at least one event happening.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This scenario is less likely since if Q occurs, it is probable that P may also occur. I will estimate this probability at 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability that assumes P happens. Given that Musk showing up could increase the likelihood of him making a statement, I will estimate this at 0.80.

I will ensure that all probability estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly focusing on the relationships between the probabilities of P, not_P, Q, and their combinations.
